The phenomenon of chunking as a memory mechanism is often attributed to George Miller, who proposed the "seven plus or minus two" rule in his 1956 paper "The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two: Some Limits on Our Capacity for Processing Information". This rule suggests that the human working memory has a limited capacity of around 7 ± 2 items, which is why people tend to group information into chunks to make it more manageable.
